conversation.content: So, um, how's the whole content creation thing, you know, working out? Kind of curious.
Oh god, it's [exhausted] honestly burning me out faster than I expected. Three years in and I'm questioning everything about why I started this whole influencer journey.
Three years? Well, that's, [chuckle], I mean, pretty impressive, uh.
Impressive feels generous, honestly. I'm making decent money now, like, around four thousand monthly, but the pressure to constantly produce content is, er, sort of eating me alive.
Four thousand? That's actually really good.
Sure, but, hmm, nobody talks about [sigh] the mental toll, actually. I haven't taken a real day off in basically eighteen months because the algorithm punishes any breaks.
So, can't you just, uhh, schedule posts ahead? I guess that's a thing?
I do batch content, yeah. But engagement tanks when people realize you're not actually there responding in real-time, and sponsors track that stuff obsessively now.
Sponsors sound demanding.
The thing is, um, I signed some contracts [very meekly] that I really shouldn't have. One brand basically owns my Thursdays for another six months.
Owns your Thursdays? That's, err, pretty weird, anyway. It's just that I've never heard of that.
They get first approval on any Thursday content, even personal posts. I was desperate for steady income when I signed it, but now it feels like selling pieces of my life.
Ah, that's rough. Well, you know, at least it ends eventually?
Yeah, in February, hmmm, but I'm [sleepily] already getting pitched similar deals, kind of. I mean, the money's tempting when rent keeps climbing.
Okay so, what would you, like, do differently if you could, uh, start over?
I'd stay anonymous, definitely. Having my real name attached to everything means I can't even vent about bad days without losing followers or disappointing brands.
Anonymous creators do pretty well though, right?
Some make millions behind avatars and usernames. Meanwhile I'm over here getting recognized at grocery stores by people who think they own me because they watch my stories.
That sounds genuinely uncomfortable.
Last week someone filmed me crying in my car after a therapy session and posted it asking if I was okay. That level of surveillance isn't worth any amount of sponsorship money.
